message.content:
Validate the guides product system for affiliate readiness. Check:

1. **Product Registry Completeness** (`src/data/guides/products-registry.ts`):
   - Every product has all required fields (id, name, brand, category, tagline, description, priority, priceRange, regionLinks, imageUrl)
   - All regionLinks have all 6 regions (us, uk, de, fr, au, asia)
   - No duplicate product IDs
   - All imageUrls are valid Unsplash URLs

2. **Guide Product References**:
   - Read all guide files in `src/data/guides/` 
   - Check that every productId referenced in guides exists in GUIDE_PRODUCTS
   - Look for any orphaned products (in registry but never used in guides)

3. **Affiliate Link Structure**:
   - Verify buildAmazonUrl function in `src/lib/region.ts` generates correct affiliate URLs
   - Check that ASIN format is valid (10 alphanumeric characters)

Report any issues found with specific file paths and line numbers.

content.content:
1→/**
     2→ * Product Registry for Guides System
     3→ * 73 products with multi-region affiliate links and Ross-style taglines
     4→ * Categories: hygiene, grooming, skincare, miscellaneous, supplements, hair, beard, teeth, kbeauty, hormonal, surgery
     5→ */
     6→
     7→import { GuideProduct, ProductCategory } from '@/types/guides';
     8→import { buildAmazonUrl } from '@/lib/region';
     9→
    10→// ============================================
    11→// AMAZON ASIN MAPPING BY REGION
    12→// ============================================
    13→
    14→interface ProductASINs {
    15→  us?: string;
    16→  uk?: string;
    17→  de?: string;
    18→  fr?: string;
    19→  au?: string;
    20→}
    21→
    22→// Regions that have Amazon stores with ASINs
    23→type AmazonRegion = 'us' | 'uk' | 'de' | 'fr' | 'au';
    24→const AMAZON_REGIONS: AmazonRegion[] = ['us', 'uk', 'de', 'fr', 'au'];
    25→
    26→// Helper to build region links from ASINs
    27→function buildRegionLinks(asins: ProductASINs): Record<string, string> {
    28→  const links: Record<string, string> = {};
    29→
    30→  AMAZON_REGIONS.forEach(region => {
    31→    const asin = asins[region] || asins.us; // Fallback to US ASIN
    32→    if (asin) {
    33→      links[region] = buildAmazonUrl(asin, region);
    34→    }
    35→  });
    36→
    37→  // Asia uses US ASIN on amzn.asia domain
    38→  if (asins.us) {
    39→    links['asia'] = buildAmazonUrl(asins.us, 'asia');
    40→  }
    41→
    42→  return links;
    43→}
    44→

    46→// PRODUCT DATABASE (33 Products)

  1298→
  1299→// ============================================
  1300→// HELPER FUNCTIONS
  1301→// ============================================
  1302→
  1303→/**
  1304→ * Product ID aliases for backwards compatibility
  1305→ * Maps shorthand IDs to full product IDs
  1306→ */
  1307→const PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES: Record<string, string> = {
  1308→  // Supplements
  1309→  ashwagandha: 'ashwagandha_ksm66',
  1310→  creatine: 'creatine_mono',
  1311→  omega_3: 'omega3_fish_oil',
  1312→  zinc: 'zinc_picolinate',
  1313→  // Add more as needed
  1314→};
  1315→
  1316→/**
  1317→ * Get product by ID (supports aliases)
  1318→ */
  1319→export function getGuideProductById(id: string): GuideProduct | undefined {
  1320→  // Resolve alias if it exists
  1321→  const resolvedId = PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES[id] || id;
  1322→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.find(p => p.id === resolvedId);
  1323→}
  1324→
  1325→/**
  1326→ * Get all products in a category
  1327→ */
  1328→export function getGuideProductsByCategory(category: ProductCategory): GuideProduct[] {
  1329→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
  1330→    .filter(p => p.category === category)
  1331→    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
  1332→}
  1333→
  1334→/**
  1335→ * Get all base stack products (essentials for everyone)
  1336→ */
  1337→export function getBaseStackProducts(): GuideProduct[] {
  1338→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
  1339→    .filter(p => p.isBaseStack)
  1340→    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
  1341→}
  1342→
  1343→/**
  1344→ * Get products by priority level
  1345→ */
  1346→export function getGuideProductsByPriority(priority: number): GuideProduct[] {
  1347→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.priority === priority);
  1348→}
  1349→
  1350→/**
  1351→ * Get all unique categories with product counts
  1352→ */
  1353→export function getProductCategories(): Array<{ category: ProductCategory; count: number }> {
  1354→  const categories: ProductCategory[] = [
  1355→    'hygiene',
  1356→    'grooming',
  1357→    'skincare',
  1358→    'miscellaneous',
  1359→    'supplements',
  1360→    'hair',
  1361→    'beard',
  1362→    'teeth',
  1363→    'kbeauty',
  1364→    'hormonal',
  1365→    'surgery',
  1366→  ];
  1367→
  1368→  return categories.map(category => ({
  1369→    category,
  1370→    count: GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.category === category).length,
  1371→  }));
  1372→}
  1373→
  1374→/**
  1375→ * Get products by array of IDs (preserves order)
  1376→ */
  1377→export function getGuideProductsByIds(ids: string[]): GuideProduct[] {
  1378→  return ids
  1379→    .map(id => getGuideProductById(id))
  1380→    .filter((p): p is GuideProduct => p !== undefined);
  1381→}
  1382→
  1383→/**
  1384→ * Search products by name or description
  1385→ */
  1386→export function searchGuideProducts(query: string): GuideProduct[] {
  1387→  const lowered = query.toLowerCase();
  1388→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p =>
  1389→    p.name.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
  1390→    p.description.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
  1391→    p.tagline.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
  1392→    (p.brand && p.brand.toLowerCase().includes(lowered))
  1393→  );
  1394→}
  1395→
  1396→/**
  1397→ * Get total product count
  1398→ */
  1399→export function getTotalProductCount(): number {
  1400→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.length;
  1401→}

/**
 * Product Registry for Guides System
 * 73 products with multi-region affiliate links and Ross-style taglines
 * Categories: hygiene, grooming, skincare, miscellaneous, supplements, hair, beard, teeth, kbeauty, hormonal, surgery
 */

import { GuideProduct, ProductCategory } from '@/types/guides';
import { buildAmazonUrl } from '@/lib/region';

// ============================================
// AMAZON ASIN MAPPING BY REGION
// ============================================

interface ProductASINs {
  us?: string;
  uk?: string;
  de?: string;
  fr?: string;
  au?: string;
}

// Regions that have Amazon stores with ASINs
type AmazonRegion = 'us' | 'uk' | 'de' | 'fr' | 'au';
const AMAZON_REGIONS: AmazonRegion[] = ['us', 'uk', 'de', 'fr', 'au'];

// Helper to build region links from ASINs
function buildRegionLinks(asins: ProductASINs): Record<string, string> {
  const links: Record<string, string> = {};

  AMAZON_REGIONS.forEach(region => {
    const asin = asins[region] || asins.us; // Fallback to US ASIN
    if (asin) {
      links[region] = buildAmazonUrl(asin, region);
    }
  });

  // Asia uses US ASIN on amzn.asia domain
  if (asins.us) {
    links['asia'] = buildAmazonUrl(asins.us, 'asia');
  }

  return links;
}

    regionLinks: buildRegionLinks({ us: 'B06WGPT9LR', uk: 'B06WGPT9LR', de: 'B06WGPT9LR', fr: 'B06WGPT9LR', au: 'B06WGPT9LR' }),
    imageUrl: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1617897903246-719242758050?w=200&h=200&fit=crop',
    isBaseStack: false,
  },
  {
    id: 'vichy_ha',
    name: 'Hyaluronic Acid Serum',
    brand: 'Vichy',
    category: 'skincare',
    tagline: "Pharmacy-grade hydration. Multi-weight HA plumps skin and holds 1000x its weight in water.",
    description: 'Apply to damp skin, layer under moisturizer. Multiple HA weights for surface and deep hydration.',
    priority: 2,
    priceRange: { min: 30, max: 40, currency: 'USD' },
    regionLinks: buildRegionLinks({ us: 'B01N7T8L4H', uk: 'B01N7T8L4H', de: 'B01N7T8L4H', fr: 'B01N7T8L4H' }),
    imageUrl: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1598440947619-2c35fc9aa908?w=200&h=200&fit=crop',
    isBaseStack: false,
  },
];

// ============================================
// HELPER FUNCTIONS
// ============================================

/**
 * Product ID aliases for backwards compatibility
 * Maps shorthand IDs to full product IDs
 */
const PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES: Record<string, string> = {
  // Supplements
  ashwagandha: 'ashwagandha_ksm66',
  creatine: 'creatine_mono',
  omega_3: 'omega3_fish_oil',
  zinc: 'zinc_picolinate',
  // Add more as needed
};

/**
 * Get product by ID (supports aliases)
 */
export function getGuideProductById(id: string): GuideProduct | undefined {
  // Resolve alias if it exists
  const resolvedId = PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES[id] || id;
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.find(p => p.id === resolvedId);
}

/**
 * Get all products in a category
 */
export function getGuideProductsByCategory(category: ProductCategory): GuideProduct[] {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
    .filter(p => p.category === category)
    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
}

/**
 * Get all base stack products (essentials for everyone)
 */
export function getBaseStackProducts(): GuideProduct[] {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
    .filter(p => p.isBaseStack)
    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
}

/**
 * Get products by priority level
 */
export function getGuideProductsByPriority(priority: number): GuideProduct[] {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.priority === priority);
}

/**
 * Get all unique categories with product counts
 */
export function getProductCategories(): Array<{ category: ProductCategory; count: number }> {
  const categories: ProductCategory[] = [
    'hygiene',
    'grooming',
    'skincare',
    'miscellaneous',
    'supplements',
    'hair',
    'beard',
    'teeth',
    'kbeauty',
    'hormonal',
    'surgery',
  ];

  return categories.map(category => ({
    category,
    count: GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.category === category).length,
  }));
}

/**
 * Get products by array of IDs (preserves order)
 */
export function getGuideProductsByIds(ids: string[]): GuideProduct[] {
  return ids
    .map(id => getGuideProductById(id))
    .filter((p): p is GuideProduct => p !== undefined);
}

/**
 * Search products by name or description
 */
export function searchGuideProducts(query: string): GuideProduct[] {
  const lowered = query.toLowerCase();
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p =>
    p.name.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
    p.description.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
    p.tagline.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
    (p.brand && p.brand.toLowerCase().includes(lowered))
  );
}

/**
 * Get total product count
 */
export function getTotalProductCount(): number {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.length;
}

/**
 * Get category display info
 */
export function getCategoryDisplayInfo(category: ProductCategory): {
  name: string;
  icon: string;
  description: string;
} {
  const info: Record<ProductCategory, { name: string; icon: string; description: string }> = {
    hygiene: {
      name: 'Hygiene',
      icon: 'Sparkles',
      description: 'Fundamentals of not repelling people',
    },
    grooming: {
      name: 'Grooming',
      icon: 'Scissors',
      description: 'Tools for precision face maintenance',
    },
    skincare: {
      name: 'Skincare',
      icon: 'Droplet',
      description: 'Your skin is your face. Treat it right.',
    },
    miscellaneous: {
      name: 'Miscellaneous',
      icon: 'Package',
      description: 'The supporting cast of your glow-up',
    },
    supplements: {
      name: 'Supplements',
      icon: 'Pill',
      description: 'Fill the gaps your diet is missing',
    },
    hair: {
      name: 'Hair',
      icon: 'Wind',
      description: 'The Big 3 and beyond—save what you have',
    },
    beard: {
      name: 'Beard',
      icon: 'User',
      description: 'Grow it, groom it, own it',
    },
    teeth: {
      name: 'Teeth',
      icon: 'Smile',
      description: 'Your smile is worth more than you think',
    },
    kbeauty: {
      name: 'K-Beauty',
      icon: 'Sparkle',
      description: 'Glass skin protocols from Seoul',
    },
    hormonal: {
      name: 'Hormonal',
      icon: 'Heart',
      description: 'PCOS, hormonal acne, and balance',
    },
    surgery: {
      name: 'Surgery',
      icon: 'Stethoscope',
      description: 'Post-op recovery essentials',
    },
  };

  return info[category];
}

   425→      title: 'Acne Scars: What Actually Works',
   426→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   427→      content: `Once acne is controlled, scars may remain. Here's what helps:
   428→
   429→**Types of Acne Scars:**
   430→- **Icepick:** Deep, narrow, V-shaped

   434→
   435→**What Actually Works:**

   437→**For Hyperpigmentation (Dark Marks):**

   444→**For True Scars (Texture):**

   480→- Omega-3s (anti-inflammatory)
   481→
   482→**Stress:**
   483→- Cortisol triggers oil production
   484→- Stress acne is real
   485→- Manage what you can
   486→
   487→**Habits:**
   488→- Don't touch your face
   489→- Clean your phone
   490→- Wash pillowcases
   491→- Don't pick at skin
   492→- Remove makeup before bed
   493→
   494→**Gym:**
   495→- Sweat can clog pores
   496→- Wipe face during workout
   497→- Shower/cleanse after
   498→- Don't use dirty towels on face
   499→
   500→**Sun:**
   501→- Some sun can temporarily help acne
   502→- But UV damage is worse long-term
   503→- Use sunscreen anyway`,
   504→    },

   507→      title: 'Routines by Goal',
   508→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   509→      content: `Customize based on your primary concern:
   510→
   511→**Goal: Basic Maintenance (No Issues)**
   512→- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
   513→- PM: Cleanse, moisturize
   514→

   525→- PM: Foaming cleanser, niacinamide serum, lightweight moisturizer
   526→
   527→**Goal: Sensitive Skin**

   530→- Add actives very slowly
   531→
   532→**Remember:**
   533→Start with basics. Add one product at a time. Wait 2-4 weeks between additions. This lets you identify what works and what causes problems.`,
   534→    },
   535→    {
   536→      id: 'accutane-nuclear',
   537→      title: 'The Nuclear Option: Accutane',
   538→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   539→      content: `When everything else fails, there's isotretinoin (Accutane). This is the only true "cure" for severe acne.
   540→
   541→**Who Should Consider It:**
   542→- Severe cystic or nodular acne
   543→- Moderate acne that hasn't responded to other treatments (3+ months)
   544→- Acne that's causing scarring
   545→- Significant psychological impact from acne
   546→
   547→**How It Works:**
   548→Accutane shrinks your oil glands by 80-90% and fundamentally changes how your skin produces sebum. Unlike other treatments, the effects are often permanent after a single course.
   549→
   550→**The Reality Check:**
   551→
   552→| Aspect | What to Expect |
   553→|--------|----------------|
   554→| **Duration** | 5-7 months typically |
   555→| **Side Effects** | Dry lips (100%), dry skin, joint pain |
   556→| **Monitoring** | Monthly blood tests, pregnancy tests (females) |
   557→| **Results** | 80-85% clearance rate, often permanent |
   558→
   559→**The iPledge Program (USA):**
   560→If you're in the US, you'll need to enroll in iPledge. This means monthly appointments, blood tests, and pregnancy prevention requirements. It's a hassle, but it's why Accutane is so safe today.
   561→
   562→**Common Side Effects:**
   563→- Extremely dry lips (Aquaphor is your new best friend)
   564→- Dry skin and eyes
   565→- Joint pain (especially lower back)
   566→- Initial purging (gets worse before better)
   567→- Sun sensitivity (sunscreen is critical)
   568→
   569→**When NOT to Take It:**
   570→- Pregnancy (causes severe birth defects)
   571→- Concurrent with tetracyclines
   572→- History of inflammatory bowel disease
   573→- Active liver disease
   574→
   575→This guide covers the basics—if you're serious about Accutane, consult a dermatologist. We'll have a full Accutane guide coming soon with month-by-month protocols.`,
   576→      products: ['aquaphor_lip', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
   577→      warnings: [
   578→        'NEVER take Accutane if pregnant or planning pregnancy',
   579→        'The purge is real—expect month 1-2 to look worse before better',
   580→        'Alcohol on Accutane stresses your liver—limit heavily or abstain'
   581→      ],
   582→    },
   583→    {
   584→      id: 'retinoids-comparison',
   585→      title: 'Prescription vs OTC Retinoids',
   586→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   587→      content: `Not all retinoids are created equal. Here's the hierarchy:
   588→
   589→**The Retinoid Ladder:**
   590→
   591→| Product | Strength | Access | Best For |
   592→|---------|----------|--------|----------|
   593→| **Tretinoin 0.1%** | Strongest | Rx only | Stubborn acne, serious anti-aging |
   594→| **Tretinoin 0.05%** | Strong | Rx only | Standard treatment strength |
   595→| **Tretinoin 0.025%** | Medium | Rx only | Beginners, sensitive skin |
   596→| **Adapalene 0.3%** | Medium | Rx only | Acne-focused treatment |
   597→| **Adapalene 0.1%** | Medium-Low | OTC (Differin) | OTC acne treatment |
   598→| **Retinol 1%** | Low-Medium | OTC | Gentle anti-aging |
   599→| **Retinol 0.5%** | Low | OTC | Beginner OTC option |
   600→| **Retinaldehyde** | Low | OTC (expensive) | Sensitive skin OTC |
   601→| **Retinyl Palmitate** | Very Low | OTC | Basically useless |
   602→
   603→**The Conversion Problem:**
   604→Your skin needs to convert OTC retinol → retinaldehyde → retinoic acid (what tretinoin already is). Each step loses potency. That's why tretinoin works faster and more effectively.
   605→
   606→**OTC Path (No Prescription):**
   607→1. Start with 0.3% retinol
   608→2. Build to 0.5% over 4-6 weeks
   609→3. Move to 1% retinol or Differin
   610→4. Use for 6-12 months before considering Rx
   611→
   612→**Prescription Path (Faster Results):**
   613→1. Get tretinoin 0.025% from dermatologist or telehealth
   614→2. Build tolerance over 6-12 weeks
   615→3. Increase to 0.05% when tolerated
   616→4. Optional: move to 0.1% for maximum efficacy

   618→**Telehealth Options:**

   620→- Apostrophe (tretinoin available)
   621→- Dermatica (UK)
   622→
   623→These services offer tretinoin without an in-person dermatologist visit.`,
   624→    },
   625→    {
   626→      id: 'dermatologist-decision',
   627→      title: 'When to See a Dermatologist',
   628→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   629→      content: `Some things you can handle at home. Others need a professional. Here's the decision tree:
   630→
   631→**See a Dermatologist If:**
   632→
   633→✅ **Acne Issues:**
   634→- Cystic/nodular acne (deep, painful, under-skin)
   635→- Acne that scars (you're running out of time)

   637→- Acne covering large areas (back, chest, face)
   638→
   639→✅ **Prescription Needs:**
   640→- Want tretinoin but can't access telehealth
   641→- Need isotretinoin (Accutane)

   644→
   645→✅ **Suspicious Spots:**
   646→- Any mole that changes in size, shape, or color
   647→- New spots that don't heal in 3 weeks
   648→- Anything that bleeds, itches, or crusts repeatedly
   649→
   650→✅ **Chronic Conditions:**
   651→- Rosacea (flushing, visible blood vessels)
   652→- Eczema/dermatitis (persistent dry, itchy patches)
   653→- Psoriasis (thick, scaly patches)

   655→
   656→**Handle at Home:**
   657→- Mild acne (occasional pimples, blackheads)
   658→- General skincare routine building
   659→- Hyperpigmentation (dark spots from healed acne)
   660→- Dry skin issues
   661→- Sun damage prevention
   662→
   663→**Cost-Effective Options:**
   664→1. **Telehealth first** — Curology, Apostrophe ($20-40/month)
   665→2. **Walk-in clinic** — Can prescribe basic Rx ($50-150)
   666→3. **Full dermatologist** — For complex cases ($150-300)
   667→
   668→**Pro Tip:** Take photos of your skin over time. Show them to your dermatologist. They can only see your skin in that moment—photos show the full picture.`,
   669→    },
   670→    {
   671→      id: 'action-plan',
   672→      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   673→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   674→      content: `Here's your step-by-step skincare implementation:
   675→
   676→**Week 1-2: Basics Only**
   677→- Buy: Cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen
   678→- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
   679→- PM: Cleanse, moisturize
   680→- Get consistent with this before adding anything
   681→
   682→**Week 3-4: Assess and Adjust**
   683→- Is skin tolerating basics well?
   684→- Any reactions to products?
   685→- Identify primary concern (acne, aging, etc.)
   686→
   687→**Month 2: Add One Active**
   688→- For acne: Start benzoyl peroxide OR tretinoin (not both)
   689→- For aging: Start tretinoin OR vitamin C (pick one)
   690→- Add slowly (2-3x/week first)
   691→
   692→**Month 3-6: Build and Maintain**
   693→- Increase frequency of actives as tolerated
   694→- Full tretinoin use (nightly) if pursuing
   695→- Evaluate progress monthly
   696→
   697→**Ongoing: Consistency**
   698→- Routine should take <5 min per session
   699→- Results come from months/years of consistency
   700→- Don't add new products constantly
   701→
   702→**Product Recommendations:**
   703→- Cleanser: CeraVe Foaming or Hydrating
   704→- Moisturizer: CeraVe PM
   705→- Sunscreen: EltaMD UV Clear
   706→- Retinoid: Tretinoin 0.025% (prescription)
   707→
   708→This is the evidence-based, no-BS approach. Simple, effective, sustainable.`,
   709→      products: ['cerave_cleanser', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta', 'tretinoin_guide'],
   710→    },
   711→  ],
   712→};

/**
 * Skincare & Acne Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const skincareGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'skincare',
  slug: 'skincare-acne',
  title: 'Skincare & Acne',
  subtitle: "Your skin is your face. Treat it right.",
  description: "Evidence-based skincare routines for clear, healthy skin. From basics to advanced treatments like tretinoin.",
  icon: 'Droplet',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 9,
  tags: ['skincare', 'acne', 'anti-aging', 'routine', 'tretinoin'],
  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat', 'diet'],
  productIds: [
    'cerave_cleanser',
    'cerave_moisturizer',
    'sunscreen_elta',
    'aquaphor_lip',
    'tretinoin_guide',
  ],
  forumCategory: 'poor-skin',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'skincare-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1556228720-195a672e8a03?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Clear, healthy skin and skincare',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Basics of Good Skin',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your skin is literally your face. It's the first thing people see, and it significantly impacts how attractive you appear.

**The Good News:**
- Skincare is not complicated
- Most improvements come from basics
- Results happen in weeks to months
- It's not expensive

**The Bad News:**
- Genetics play a role
- Some things take time
- There are no overnight fixes
- Consistency is required

**What Actually Works:**
1. Cleanser (clean skin)
2. Moisturizer (healthy barrier)
3. Sunscreen (prevent damage)
4. Tretinoin (for acne/anti-aging)

That's the core. Everything else is optimization.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'routine-basics',
      title: 'The Basic Routine',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Start here. Master this before adding anything else.

**Morning Routine (2 minutes):**
1. Rinse face with water (or gentle cleanser if oily)
2. Apply moisturizer
3. Apply sunscreen (non-negotiable)

**Evening Routine (3 minutes):**
1. Cleanse face (remove dirt, oil, sunscreen)
2. Apply any actives (tretinoin, etc.)
3. Apply moisturizer

**That's It.**

Don't overcomplicate. Don't buy 10 products because TikTok said so. The basic routine done consistently beats a 12-step routine done sporadically.

**Order Matters:**
Thinnest to thickest consistency:
1. Cleansers (remove)
2. Toners/serums (watery actives)
3. Treatments (tretinoin, etc.)
4. Moisturizer (seal it in)
5. Sunscreen (protect from sun)`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'skincare-routine-infographic',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/0513/2409/files/mens_skin_care_routine_infographic.png',
          alt: 'Men\'s daily skincare routine infographic',
          caption: 'The basic skincare routine for all skin types',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'kdrama-facemask-gif',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/1npaSqEUpFvZ5H9dqK/giphy.gif',
          alt: 'Korean drama face mask scene',
          caption: 'Even K-drama stars do their skincare routine',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'cleansing',
      title: 'Cleansing: Do It Right',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Most guys either skip cleansing or do it wrong.

**The Goal:**
Remove dirt, oil, sweat, and sunscreen without stripping your skin.

**How to Cleanse:**
1. Wet face with lukewarm water (not hot)
2. Apply dime-sized amount of cleanser
3. Massage gently for 30-60 seconds
4. Rinse thoroughly
5. Pat dry (don't rub)

**Choosing a Cleanser:**

| Skin Type | Cleanser Type |
|-----------|---------------|
| Oily/Acne | Foaming/gel cleanser |
| Normal | Either works |
| Dry/Sensitive | Cream/hydrating cleanser |

**Recommended:** CeraVe Foaming (oily) or CeraVe Hydrating (dry)

**Common Mistakes:**
1. Over-cleansing (2x daily max)
2. Hot water (damages barrier)
3. Harsh scrubs (causes irritation)
4. Not rinsing fully (leaves residue)
5. Rubbing with towel (causes friction)

**The Feel:**
After cleansing, skin should feel clean but not tight or squeaky. If it feels stripped, your cleanser is too harsh.`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser'],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'cleansing-technique',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media1.tenor.com/m/WiFCFmsD9_oAAAAC/scrubbing-face-skincare.gif',
          alt: 'Face cleansing technique',
          caption: 'Gentle circular motions for 30-60 seconds',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'face-wash-demo',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media1.tenor.com/m/81EMyjB1X9IAAAAC/washing-face-getting-ready.gif',
          alt: 'Proper face washing technique',
          caption: 'Rinse thoroughly with lukewarm water',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'moisturizing',
      title: 'Moisturizing: Seal It In',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `A healthy skin barrier is the foundation of good skin.

**Why Moisturize:**
- Prevents water loss
- Repairs barrier function
- Reduces sensitivity
- Makes skin look healthier
- Required if using actives like tretinoin

**When:**
- Morning (after cleansing, before sunscreen)
- Evening (after actives or as last step)

**Choosing a Moisturizer:**

| Skin Type | Texture |
|-----------|---------|
| Oily | Lightweight/gel moisturizer |
| Normal | Lotion texture |
| Dry | Cream texture |

**Recommended:** CeraVe PM (lightweight), CeraVe Cream (thicker)

**Key Ingredients to Look For:**
- Ceramides (barrier repair)
- Hyaluronic acid (hydration)
- Niacinamide (reduces pores, calms skin)
- Glycerin (hydration)

**Application:**
- Apply to slightly damp skin for better absorption
- Use enough to cover face without being greasy
- Don't forget neck`,
      products: ['cerave_moisturizer'],
    },
    {
      id: 'sunscreen',
      title: 'Sunscreen: The Anti-Aging Essential',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Sun damage is the biggest scam your skin is running on your future self. Block it.

**The Reality:**
- 80% of visible skin aging is from sun exposure
- UV damage accumulates over years
- By the time you see damage, it's already been happening for a decade
- Sunscreen is the #1 anti-aging product

**The Protocol:**
- SPF 30 minimum, SPF 50 preferred
- Apply every morning (yes, even cloudy days)
- Reapply every 2 hours if outdoors
- About 1/4 teaspoon for face

**Choosing Sunscreen:**

**Chemical Sunscreens:**
- Absorbs into skin, absorbs UV rays
- More cosmetically elegant
- May sting eyes or irritate some skin
- Examples: Avobenzone, oxybenzone, octinoxate

**Mineral Sunscreens:**
- Sits on skin, reflects UV rays
- Can leave white cast
- Better for sensitive skin
- Examples: Zinc oxide, titanium dioxide

**Recommended:** EltaMD UV Clear SPF 46 (best for acne-prone skin)

**The Excuses (And Why They're Wrong):**
- "I don't burn" → UV damage happens regardless
- "I'm indoors" → UVA goes through windows
- "It's cloudy" → 80% of UV penetrates clouds
- "Sunscreen causes acne" → Get a better sunscreen`,
      products: ['sunscreen_elta'],
      warnings: [
        'Skipping sunscreen will undo your other skincare efforts',
        'Reapply if outdoors for extended periods'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'sunscreen-amount',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1532413992378-f169ac26fff0?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Sunscreen and sun protection',
          caption: 'Use about 1/4 teaspoon (two finger lengths) for your face',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'acne',
      title: 'Acne: Understanding and Treating',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Acne is the most common skin concern. Here's how to actually treat it.

**What Causes Acne:**
1. Excess sebum (oil) production
2. Dead skin cells clogging pores
3. Bacteria (C. acnes)
4. Inflammation

**Types of Acne:**
- **Comedonal:** Blackheads and whiteheads (clogged pores)
- **Inflammatory:** Red, swollen pimples
- **Cystic:** Deep, painful, scarring

**Treatment Hierarchy:**

**Level 1: Basic Routine**
- Consistent cleansing
- Non-comedogenic moisturizer
- Often fixes mild acne

**Level 2: Over-the-Counter Actives**
- Benzoyl peroxide (kills bacteria)
- Salicylic acid (unclogs pores)
- Adapalene/Differin (retinoid, OTC)

**Level 3: Prescription**
- Tretinoin (see next section)
- Antibiotics (temporary)
- Spironolactone (hormonal, for women)

**Level 4: Accutane/Isotretinoin**
- Nuclear option for severe or resistant acne
- 4-6 month course, usually permanent results
- Side effects but highly effective
- Requires dermatologist

**General Rules:**
- Be patient (6-12 weeks for actives to work)
- Don't pick (causes scarring)
- Change pillowcase frequently
- Clean phone screen`,
    },
    {
      id: 'tretinoin',
      title: 'Tretinoin: The Gold Standard',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Tretinoin (prescription retinoid) is the most evidence-backed skincare ingredient for both acne and anti-aging.

**What It Does:**
- Increases cell turnover
- Unclogs pores
- Reduces acne
- Fades dark spots
- Reduces fine lines
- Improves skin texture

**How to Get It:**
- Dermatologist prescription
- Online telemedicine (Curology, Apostrophe)
- Some countries: OTC

**Starting Protocol (Critical):**

**Week 1-2:** 2x per week only
**Week 3-4:** Every other night
**Week 5-6:** Every night (if tolerated)
**Ongoing:** Nightly, thin layer

**The Retinization Period:**
Expect 4-12 weeks of:
- Dryness
- Peeling
- Redness
- Possible purging (temporary increase in acne)

This is normal. Push through carefully. It gets better.

**Application Tips:**
1. Apply to completely dry skin (wait 20 min after washing)
2. Pea-sized amount for entire face
3. Avoid eye area initially
4. Follow with moisturizer
5. Use sunscreen daily (skin is more sensitive)

**Don't Use With:**
- Benzoyl peroxide (inactivates tret)
- Vitamin C (morning only)
- Other strong actives initially

**The Payoff:**
12-month mark is where the magic happens. Consistent tretinoin use genuinely reverses aging and transforms skin.`,
      products: ['tretinoin_guide', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
      warnings: [
        'Start low and slow—0.025% is enough initially',
        'Over-application causes more irritation, not faster results',
        'Tretinoin + sun exposure = damage. Always use sunscreen.'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'tretinoin-application',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1620916566398-39f1143ab7be?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Skincare product application',
          caption: 'Pea-sized amount, dot on forehead, cheeks, chin, then spread',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'tretinoin-timeline',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1598440947619-2c35fc9aa908?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Skincare progress and results',
          caption: 'Expect 3-6 months for initial improvement, 12+ for full results',
          placement: 'full-width',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'skin-type',
      title: 'Know Your Skin Type',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your skin type determines product selection.

**Oily Skin:**
- Shiny by midday
- Visible pores
- Prone to acne
- Needs: Gel cleansers, lightweight moisturizers, mattifying products

**Dry Skin:**
- Feels tight
- Flaking or rough texture
- Fine lines more visible
- Needs: Cream cleansers, rich moisturizers, hydrating ingredients

**Combination Skin:**
- Oily T-zone (forehead, nose, chin)
- Dry cheeks
- Most common type
- Needs: Balanced approach, zone-specific treatment

**Sensitive Skin:**
- Reacts easily to products
- Redness, stinging
- Needs: Fragrance-free, minimal ingredients, patch testing

**Normal Skin:**
- Balanced
- Few issues
- Needs: Basic maintenance

**How to Test:**
1. Wash face, wait 30 minutes
2. Don't apply anything
3. Observe how skin feels and looks

If shiny → oily
If tight → dry
If both → combination
If irritated → sensitive
If fine → normal`,
    },
    {
      id: 'acne-scarring',
      title: 'Acne Scars: What Actually Works',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Once acne is controlled, scars may remain. Here's what helps:

**Types of Acne Scars:**
- **Icepick:** Deep, narrow, V-shaped
- **Boxcar:** Wide, box-like depressions
- **Rolling:** Wave-like, uneven surface
- **Hyperpigmentation:** Dark marks (not true scars)

**What Actually Works:**

**For Hyperpigmentation (Dark Marks):**
- Time (fades naturally in 3-12 months)
- Tretinoin (speeds fading)
- Vitamin C (morning antioxidant)
- Niacinamide (in moisturizer)
- Sunscreen (prevents darkening)

**For True Scars (Texture):**
- Tretinoin (mild improvement over years)
- Microneedling (professional, 4-6 sessions)
- Chemical peels (professional, multiple sessions)
- Laser resurfacing (fractional CO2 or Fraxel)
- Subcision (for tethered scars)
- TCA Cross (for icepick scars)

**The Reality:**
- OTC products can't fix true textural scars
- Professional treatments are needed
- Multiple sessions required
- Results are improvement, not perfection
- Cost: $200-500+ per session

**Priority:**
1. Get acne under control first (stop creating new scars)
2. Wait for active breakouts to clear
3. Then address scarring`,
    },
    {
      id: 'lifestyle-factors',
      title: 'Lifestyle Factors for Clear Skin',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your routine matters, but so does everything else:

**Sleep:**
- 7-9 hours for skin repair
- Poor sleep = inflammation = worse skin
- Sleep on clean pillowcases (change 2x/week)
- Silk pillowcase reduces friction

**Diet:**
- High glycemic foods may worsen acne
- Dairy is problematic for some people
- Stay hydrated (not magic, but helps)
- Omega-3s (anti-inflammatory)

**Stress:**
- Cortisol triggers oil production
- Stress acne is real
- Manage what you can

**Habits:**
- Don't touch your face
- Clean your phone
- Wash pillowcases
- Don't pick at skin
- Remove makeup before bed

**Gym:**
- Sweat can clog pores
- Wipe face during workout
- Shower/cleanse after
- Don't use dirty towels on face

**Sun:**
- Some sun can temporarily help acne
- But UV damage is worse long-term
- Use sunscreen anyway`,
    },
    {
      id: 'routine-by-goal',
      title: 'Routines by Goal',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Customize based on your primary concern:

**Goal: Basic Maintenance (No Issues)**
- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, moisturize

**Goal: Acne Control**
- AM: Cleanse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, tretinoin (or benzoyl peroxide), moisturize

**Goal: Anti-Aging**
- AM: Cleanse, vitamin C serum, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, tretinoin, moisturize

**Goal: Oily Skin Control**
- AM: Foaming cleanser, lightweight moisturizer, mattifying sunscreen
- PM: Foaming cleanser, niacinamide serum, lightweight moisturizer

**Goal: Sensitive Skin**
- AM: Water rinse, fragrance-free moisturizer, mineral sunscreen
- PM: Gentle cleanser, fragrance-free moisturizer
- Add actives very slowly

**Remember:**
Start with basics. Add one product at a time. Wait 2-4 weeks between additions. This lets you identify what works and what causes problems.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'accutane-nuclear',
      title: 'The Nuclear Option: Accutane',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `When everything else fails, there's isotretinoin (Accutane). This is the only true "cure" for severe acne.

**Who Should Consider It:**
- Severe cystic or nodular acne
- Moderate acne that hasn't responded to other treatments (3+ months)
- Acne that's causing scarring
- Significant psychological impact from acne

**How It Works:**
Accutane shrinks your oil glands by 80-90% and fundamentally changes how your skin produces sebum. Unlike other treatments, the effects are often permanent after a single course.

**The Reality Check:**

| Aspect | What to Expect |
|--------|----------------|
| **Duration** | 5-7 months typically |
| **Side Effects** | Dry lips (100%), dry skin, joint pain |
| **Monitoring** | Monthly blood tests, pregnancy tests (females) |
| **Results** | 80-85% clearance rate, often permanent |

**The iPledge Program (USA):**
If you're in the US, you'll need to enroll in iPledge. This means monthly appointments, blood tests, and pregnancy prevention requirements. It's a hassle, but it's why Accutane is so safe today.

**Common Side Effects:**
- Extremely dry lips (Aquaphor is your new best friend)
- Dry skin and eyes
- Joint pain (especially lower back)
- Initial purging (gets worse before better)
- Sun sensitivity (sunscreen is critical)

**When NOT to Take It:**
- Pregnancy (causes severe birth defects)
- Concurrent with tetracyclines
- History of inflammatory bowel disease
- Active liver disease

This guide covers the basics—if you're serious about Accutane, consult a dermatologist. We'll have a full Accutane guide coming soon with month-by-month protocols.`,

      id: 'retinoids-comparison',
      title: 'Prescription vs OTC Retinoids',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Not all retinoids are created equal. Here's the hierarchy:

**The Retinoid Ladder:**

| Product | Strength | Access | Best For |
|---------|----------|--------|----------|
| **Tretinoin 0.1%** | Strongest | Rx only | Stubborn acne, serious anti-aging |
| **Tretinoin 0.05%** | Strong | Rx only | Standard treatment strength |
| **Tretinoin 0.025%** | Medium | Rx only | Beginners, sensitive skin |
| **Adapalene 0.3%** | Medium | Rx only | Acne-focused treatment |
| **Adapalene 0.1%** | Medium-Low | OTC (Differin) | OTC acne treatment |
| **Retinol 1%** | Low-Medium | OTC | Gentle anti-aging |
| **Retinol 0.5%** | Low | OTC | Beginner OTC option |
| **Retinaldehyde** | Low | OTC (expensive) | Sensitive skin OTC |
| **Retinyl Palmitate** | Very Low | OTC | Basically useless |

**The Conversion Problem:**
Your skin needs to convert OTC retinol → retinaldehyde → retinoic acid (what tretinoin already is). Each step loses potency. That's why tretinoin works faster and more effectively.

**OTC Path (No Prescription):**
1. Start with 0.3% retinol
2. Build to 0.5% over 4-6 weeks
3. Move to 1% retinol or Differin
4. Use for 6-12 months before considering Rx

**Prescription Path (Faster Results):**
1. Get tretinoin 0.025% from dermatologist or telehealth
2. Build tolerance over 6-12 weeks
3. Increase to 0.05% when tolerated
4. Optional: move to 0.1% for maximum efficacy

**Telehealth Options:**
- Curology (custom formulations, $20-30/month)
- Apostrophe (tretinoin available)
- Dermatica (UK)

These services offer tretinoin without an in-person dermatologist visit.`,

✅ **Acne Issues:**
- Cystic/nodular acne (deep, painful, under-skin)
- Acne that scars (you're running out of time)
- No improvement after 3 months of OTC treatment
- Acne covering large areas (back, chest, face)

✅ **Prescription Needs:**
- Want tretinoin but can't access telehealth
- Need isotretinoin (Accutane)
- Hormonal acne (women: may need spironolactone)
- Need antibiotics (short-term)

✅ **Suspicious Spots:**
- Any mole that changes in size, shape, or color
- New spots that don't heal in 3 weeks
- Anything that bleeds, itches, or crusts repeatedly

✅ **Chronic Conditions:**
- Rosacea (flushing, visible blood vessels)
- Eczema/dermatitis (persistent dry, itchy patches)
- Psoriasis (thick, scaly patches)
- Melasma (hormonal dark patches)

**Handle at Home:**
- Mild acne (occasional pimples, blackheads)
- General skincare routine building
- Hyperpigmentation (dark spots from healed acne)
- Dry skin issues
- Sun damage prevention

**Cost-Effective Options:**
1. **Telehealth first** — Curology, Apostrophe ($20-40/month)
2. **Walk-in clinic** — Can prescribe basic Rx ($50-150)
3. **Full dermatologist** — For complex cases ($150-300)

**Pro Tip:** Take photos of your skin over time. Show them to your dermatologist. They can only see your skin in that moment—photos show the full picture.`,

**Week 1-2: Basics Only**

**Week 3-4: Assess and Adjust**

**Month 2: Add One Active**

**Month 3-6: Build and Maintain**

**Ongoing: Consistency**

- Results come from months/years of consistency

**Product Recommendations:**

- Moisturizer: CeraVe PM

- Retinoid: Tretinoin 0.025% (prescription)

This is the evidence-based, no-BS approach. Simple, effective, sustainable.`,

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

/**
 * General Maintenance Guide
 * Humor Level: High (25%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const maintenanceGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'maintenance',
  slug: 'general-maintenance',
  title: 'General Maintenance',
  subtitle: "The bare minimum that most guys still somehow miss",
  description: "Daily and weekly grooming habits that separate you from the NPCs. Non-negotiable baseline stuff.",
  icon: 'Wrench',
  humorLevel: 'high',
  estimatedReadTime: 10,
  order: 2,
  tags: ['grooming', 'hygiene', 'daily-routine', 'fundamentals'],
  relatedGuides: ['mindset', 'skincare'],
  productIds: [
    'tongue_scraper',
    'electric_toothbrush',
    'philips_oneblade',
    'nose_trimmer',
    'tweezers',
    'aquaphor_lip',
    'cologne_bleu',
  ],
  forumCategory: 'fashion',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'maintenance-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1519085360753-af0119f7cbe7?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Clean, well-groomed appearance',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The NPC Baseline',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Here's something that might hurt: most guys walking around have absolutely no idea how many basic maintenance things they're neglecting.

Nostril tentacles waving at people mid-conversation. Crusty lips. Unibrow situation developing. Breath that could clear a room.

**Nobody tells you this stuff.** Your friends won't. Your family's given up. Tinder matches just unmatch without explanation.

This guide is the checklist. The bare minimum. The "if you're not doing this, nothing else matters" baseline.

Everything here is simple. Nothing is expensive. No excuses.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'daily-oral',
      title: 'Daily: Oral Hygiene',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Your breath is out here committing war crimes and you don't even know it.

**The Protocol:**
1. **Brush 2x daily** — Electric toothbrush, 2 minutes minimum. If you're using a manual toothbrush in 2024, that's NPC behavior.
2. **Floss daily** — Yes, actually. The stuff between your teeth is rotting. Get string floss or a water flosser.
3. **Tongue scrape** — This is the secret weapon. 70% of bad breath comes from bacteria on your tongue. Takes 10 seconds, changes everything.

**The Reality Check:**
- You can't smell your own breath
- Everyone's too polite to tell you
- This is actively limiting your social and romantic life
- Fix it now`,
      products: ['tongue_scraper', 'electric_toothbrush'],
      tips: [
        'Scrape tongue BEFORE brushing, not after',
        'Replace toothbrush head every 3 months',
        'Mouthwash is optional but flossing is mandatory'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'tongue-scraping',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1606107557195-0e29a4b5b4aa?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Oral hygiene and dental care products',
          caption: 'Oral hygiene: brush, floss, scrape',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'daily-lips',
      title: 'Daily: Lip Care',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Crusty, chapped lips are sabotaging your entire face. The fix costs $5.

**Why This Matters:**
Your lips are one of the first things people notice. Dry, cracked lips read as "doesn't take care of himself" instantly.

**The Fix:**
- Apply lip balm or Aquaphor morning and night
- Reapply after eating or drinking
- At night, use a heavier occlusive (Aquaphor > chapstick)

**Common Mistakes:**
- Licking your lips (makes it worse)
- Flavored lip balms (you'll lick them)
- Forgetting entirely (check your lips right now)

**Pro tip:** Keep one by your bed, one in your pocket, one at your desk. The best lip balm is the one you actually use.`,
      products: ['aquaphor_lip'],
    },
    {
      id: 'weekly-nose-ear',
      title: 'Weekly: Nose & Ear Hair',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Nostril tentacles waving at people mid-conversation is an instant mog-killer. Nobody's going to tell you—they'll just slowly lose attraction and not know why.

**The Protocol:**
- Trim nose hairs weekly (Sunday maintenance)
- Check ear hair too (yes, you have some)
- Use a proper trimmer, not scissors (you WILL cut yourself)

**The Psychology:**
People rarely notice good grooming here, but they DEFINITELY notice when you neglect it. It's one of those things that can only hurt you, never help. Just eliminate it.

Get a trimmer. Use it weekly. This is bare minimum NPC maintenance, and you're not an NPC.`,
      products: ['nose_trimmer'],
      warnings: [
        "Don't use scissors inside your nose",
        "Don't pluck nose hairs (infection risk)"
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'weekly-eyebrows',
      title: 'Weekly: Eyebrow Maintenance',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `There's a zone between "unibrow" and "Instagram influencer overplucked" that you're aiming for.

**What to Do:**
1. **Define the gap** — There should be clear separation between brows. Pluck strays between them.
2. **Clean the edges** — Remove random hairs above and below the brow line.
3. **Don't reshape** — You're cleaning, not redesigning. Keep your natural brow shape.

**What NOT to Do:**
- Don't thin them out (thicker brows = more masculine)
- Don't create an artificial arch
- Don't touch the main body of the brow
- Don't wax (too aggressive for maintenance)

**The Goal:**
Clean and intentional, not "did someone do your eyebrows?" If people can tell you've groomed them, you've gone too far.`,
      products: ['tweezers'],
      tips: [
        'Pluck after shower when pores are open',
        'Use natural light, bathroom lighting lies',
        'Take a step back every few hairs to check balance'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'weekly-facial-hair',
      title: 'Weekly: Facial Hair Management',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Whether you're going clean-shaven, stubble, or full beard—it needs to look intentional, not accidental.

**Clean-Shaven:**
- Shave every 1-3 days depending on growth
- Use a proper shave cream (not canned foam)
- Shave with the grain first, then against if needed
- Moisturize after

**Stubble:**
- This is the sweet spot for most faces
- Maintain at 1-3mm with a trimmer
- Clean up the neck and cheek lines
- Edge the mustache above the lip line

**Beard:**
- Keep it trimmed and shaped
- Define the neckline (2 fingers above Adam's apple)
- Use beard oil if longer than 1 week growth
- Wash it (yes, like hair)

**The Key:** Whatever style you choose, it should look like a choice, not like you ran out of razors.`,
      products: ['philips_oneblade', 'shaving_cream'],
    },
    {
      id: 'nails',
      title: 'Weekly: Nail Care',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Women notice nails immediately. Dirty, long, or bitten nails are an instant credibility killer.

**The Standard:**
- Trim weekly
- File rough edges (yes, men can use nail files)
- Clean under nails daily
- Push back cuticles after shower (optional but clean look)

**What You're Avoiding:**
- Nails that extend past fingertips
- Visible dirt under nails
- Ragged, bitten edges
- Hangnails

**No man has ever lost points for having clean, trimmed nails. Many have lost points for the opposite.**`,
      tips: [
        'Cut after shower when nails are softer',
        'Straight across, then round the corners slightly',
        "Keep a nail brush by the sink if you work with your hands"
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'fragrance',
      title: 'Daily: Scent Protocol',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Stop smelling like your high school gym locker. This ain't Axe bodyspray era anymore.

**The Layers:**
1. **Base** — Shower daily with unscented or lightly scented soap
2. **Deodorant** — Antiperspirant, applied at night (not morning)
3. **Fragrance** — 2-3 sprays MAX of a quality cologne

**Application:**
- Spray on pulse points: wrists, neck, chest
- Don't rub wrists together (breaks down scent)
- Less is more—you want a "lean in" scent, not an announcement

**Cologne Investment:**
One quality fragrance beats five cheap ones. Bleu de Chanel or similar safe bet. Get compliments, not complaints.

**The Test:** If people can smell you from more than arm's length, you've applied too much.`,
      products: ['cologne_bleu'],
      warnings: [
        'Never spray directly on clothes (stains and alters scent)',
        "Don't reapply throughout the day—your nose adapts, others can still smell it"
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'hair',
      title: 'Daily: Hair Maintenance',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your hair is a major factor in your overall look. Neglecting it shows.

**Daily:**
- Style it. Every day. Even if it's a 2-minute routine.
- Use product appropriate to your hair type (matte for thin, pomade for thick)
- Don't touch it throughout the day (transfers oil)

**Every 4-6 Weeks:**
- Get it cut by a real barber
- Find a style that works for your face shape and hair type
- Bring reference photos (they're not just for women)

**Washing:**
- Most guys over-wash (strips natural oils)
- Every 2-3 days is usually enough
- Use conditioner if your hair is longer than 1 inch

**If Thinning:**
- Accept it early or treat it early
- Minoxidil + finasteride (consult a doctor)
- Or just buzz it—a clean shave beats a comb-over every time`,
      tips: [
        'Find one style and master it rather than switching constantly',
        'Take photos of good haircuts to show your barber',
        'Products for hold: wax > pomade > gel > mousse'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'hair-thinning',
      title: 'Hair Maintenance for Thinning Hair',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `If you're noticing recession or thinning, you've got two choices: treat it or accept it. There's no middle ground of denial.

**Recognize the Signs Early:**
- Hairline moving back at temples (receding)
- Crown getting thinner (you can't see it, but others can)
- More hair in the drain/pillow
- Scalp visible under bright lights

**The Treatment Stack (The "Big 3"):**

| Treatment | What It Does | Cost |
|-----------|--------------|------|
| **Minoxidil 5%** | Stimulates follicles, extends growth phase | $20-40/6 months |
| **Finasteride 1mg** | Blocks DHT, stops progression | $10-30/month |
| **Ketoconazole Shampoo** | Anti-inflammatory, mild DHT blocker | $15/bottle |

**Timeline:**
- Months 1-3: Possible shedding (normal, it's working)
- Months 4-6: Stabilization, slowed loss
- Months 6-12: Regrowth begins for responders
- Year 1+: Maintenance mode

**The Decision:**
If you're going to treat, start NOW. The earlier you start, the more hair you save. Once a follicle is dead, it's gone.

**The Alternative:**
If treatment isn't for you, own the look:
- Buzz it short or shave clean
- Grow a beard if you can (bald + beard is a classic look)
- Get lean—face definition matters more when hair is gone
- Confidence > coping

We'll have a full hair loss guide coming soon. For now, don't wait—decide early.`,
      tips: [
        'Minoxidil can cause initial shedding—this is normal and temporary',
        'Apply minoxidil to DRY scalp, not wet',
        'Finasteride side effects are rare (1-2%) but discuss with doctor'
      ],
      warnings: [
        "Don't waste money on 'hair growth' supplements—most don't work",
        "Comb-overs fool nobody. Either treat it or embrace it."
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'beard-maintenance',
      title: 'Beard Maintenance & Growth',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Whether you're trying to grow a beard or maintain one, here's what actually matters:

**If You Can Grow One:**

**Stubble (1-5mm):**
- Trim every 2-3 days
- This is often the most attractive option for most faces
- Clean neckline 2 fingers above Adam's apple
- Edge cheek line naturally

**Short Beard (5-10mm):**
- Trim weekly with guard
- Use beard oil after showering
- Keep edges sharp

**Full Beard (10mm+):**
- Wash with beard shampoo
- Apply beard oil or balm daily
- Comb/brush to train direction
- Trim every 1-2 weeks for shape
- Consider a barber for initial shaping

**If You CAN'T Grow One (Yet):**

The Minoxidil beard protocol works for many guys:
1. Apply minoxidil 5% to cheeks 2x daily
2. Wait 6-24 months (yes, it takes time)
3. Vellus hairs → Terminal hairs
4. Once terminal, effects are permanent
5. Add dermarolling 0.5mm weekly for better absorption

**Important:** This is off-label use. Results vary. Most guys see significant improvement, but genetics still matter.

**Patchy Beard Solutions:**
- Let it grow longer—length hides patches
- Strategic trimming to balance density
- Focus on stubble length if very patchy
- Some patches fill in over time (give it 3-6 months)

We'll have a full beard growth guide with protocols coming soon.`,
      tips: [
        'Beard growth often improves into your 30s',
        'Minoxidil on beard can cause dryness—moisturize',
        "Don't compare your beard at 22 to someone's at 32"
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'checklist',
      title: 'The Weekly Checklist',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Print this. Put it on your bathroom mirror. No excuses.

**Daily:**
- [ ] Brush teeth (AM + PM)
- [ ] Floss
- [ ] Tongue scrape
- [ ] Apply lip balm
- [ ] Deodorant (night)
- [ ] Style hair
- [ ] Check mirror before leaving

**Weekly (Sunday Reset):**
- [ ] Trim nose/ear hair
- [ ] Eyebrow cleanup
- [ ] Facial hair maintenance
- [ ] Nail trim
- [ ] Deep clean ears

**Monthly:**
- [ ] Haircut
- [ ] Replace toothbrush head
- [ ] Inventory grooming supplies

**This is the baseline.** This is what separates "that guy takes care of himself" from "what's that smell?"

Lock in.`,
    },
  ],
};

content.content:
1→/**
     2→ * Mindset & Beginner Mistakes Guide
     3→ * Humor Level: High (30%)
     4→ */
     5→
     6→import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';
     7→
     8→export const mindsetGuide: Guide = {
     9→  id: 'mindset',
    10→  slug: 'mindset-mistakes',
    11→  title: 'Mindset & Beginner Mistakes',
    12→  subtitle: "The cope stops here",
    13→  description: "Before you spend a dime, fix the mental game. Most guys sabotage themselves before they even start.",
    14→  icon: 'Brain',
    15→  humorLevel: 'high',
    16→  estimatedReadTime: 8,
    17→  order: 1,
    18→  tags: ['mindset', 'beginners', 'fundamentals'],
    19→  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat'],
    20→  productIds: [],
    21→  forumCategory: 'anxiety',
    22→  heroMedia: {
    23→    id: 'mindset-hero',
    24→    type: 'image',
    25→    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1507003211169-0a1dd7228f2d?w=1200&q=80',
    26→    alt: 'Focused mindset and determination',
    27→    placement: 'hero',
    28→  },
    29→  sections: [
    30→    {
    31→      id: 'intro',
    32→      title: 'The Real Talk',
    33→      humorLevel: 'high',
    34→      content: `You're here because you want to look better. Good. That's the first step.
    35→
    36→But here's what nobody tells you: **most guys fail not because they don't know what to do, but because their mindset is cooked from day one.**
    37→
    38→They're either:
    39→- Paralyzed by analysis (reading guides instead of taking action)
    40→- Expecting overnight results (then quitting after 2 weeks)
    41→- Comparing themselves to genetic outliers (and feeling defeated)
    42→- Looking for shortcuts (spoiler: there aren't any)
    43→
    44→This guide is about fixing that before you waste months spinning your wheels.`,
    45→      media: [
    46→        {
    47→          id: 'mindset-intro',
    48→          type: 'image',
    49→          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1552674605-db6ffd4facb5?w=800&q=80',
    50→          alt: 'Man focused on goals',
    51→          caption: 'The mindset game starts before everything else',
    52→          placement: 'inline',
    53→        },
    54→        {
    55→          id: 'level-up-gif',
    56→          type: 'gif',
    57→          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/H9l0FtwC2hA3V7Bj5H/giphy.gif',
    58→          alt: 'Level Up pixel animation',
    59→          caption: 'Time to level up',
    60→          placement: 'inline',
    61→        },
    62→      ],
    63→    },
    64→    {
    65→      id: 'mistake-1-perfectionism',
    66→      title: 'Mistake #1: Waiting for the "Perfect" Plan',
    67→      humorLevel: 'high',
    68→      content: `You've bookmarked 47 articles. You've saved 200 Instagram posts. You've downloaded 12 PDFs. You've done exactly **zero** actual work.
    69→
    70→**This ain't it, chief.**
    71→
    72→The perfect routine doesn't exist. There's no secret combination of products and exercises that will unlock chad-tier genetics. There's just consistent effort over time.
    73→
    74→Here's the brutal truth: a mediocre plan executed consistently beats a perfect plan you never start.
    75→
    76→**Action Step:** Pick ONE thing from this app to improve. Just one. Do it for 30 days before adding anything else.`,
    77→      tips: [
    78→        'Done is better than perfect',
    79→        'Consistency beats intensity every single time',
    80→        'Start before you feel ready'
    81→      ],
    82→      media: [
    83→        {
    84→          id: 'perfectionism-trap',
    85→          type: 'image',
    86→          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1484480974693-6ca0a78fb36b?w=800&q=80',
    87→          alt: 'Planning and action',
    88→          caption: 'Stop planning, start doing',
    89→          placement: 'inline',
    90→        },
    91→      ],
    92→    },
    93→    {
    94→      id: 'mistake-2-timeline',
    95→      title: 'Mistake #2: Expecting Fast Results',
    96→      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
    97→      content: `You started mewing yesterday and you're checking your jawline in the mirror this morning. Bro.
    98→
    99→Real change takes **months to years**, depending on what you're working on:
   100→
   101→| Change | Timeline |
   102→|--------|----------|
   103→| Better skin (routine) | 6-12 weeks |
   104→| Body recomposition | 3-6 months |
   105→| Posture improvement | 3-6 months |
   106→| Hair regrowth (minox) | 6-12 months |
   107→| Mewing (adults) | 1-2+ years |
   108→
   109→**The guys who win are the ones who forget about results and just lock in on the process.**
   110→
   111→Think about it: if you had started 6 months ago, you'd already be there. You didn't. So start now and stop checking daily.`,
   112→      warnings: [
   113→        'Taking progress photos daily will drive you insane',
   114→        'Monthly or bi-monthly comparison photos are enough'
   115→      ],
   116→    },
   117→    {
   118→      id: 'mistake-3-comparison',
   119→      title: 'Mistake #3: Comparing to Genetic Outliers',
   120→      humorLevel: 'high',
   121→      content: `You're comparing yourself to guys who:
   122→- Won the genetic lottery
   123→- Have professional lighting in every photo
   124→- Are on gear and won't admit it
   125→- Use filters/editing
   126→- Got surgery and claim "just mewing bro"
   127→
   128→**This is NPC behavior.**
   129→
   130→Here's a better frame: you're not trying to become someone else. You're trying to mog your past self. That's it.
   131→
   132→Your only competition is the guy you were 6 months ago. If he'd be jealous of where you are now, you're winning.`,
   133→      tips: [
   134→        'Mog your past self, not strangers on the internet',
   135→        'Unfollow accounts that make you feel like garbage',
   136→        'Follow for information, not comparison'
   137→      ],
   138→    },
   139→    {
   140→      id: 'mistake-4-shortcuts',
   141→      title: 'Mistake #4: Looking for Shortcuts',
   142→      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   143→      content: `There are no shortcuts. There are no hacks. There is no "one weird trick."
   144→
   145→The internet is full of people trying to sell you things you don't need:
   146→- Miracle supplements that do nothing
   147→- Expensive gadgets that collect dust
   148→- "Secret" techniques that are just repackaged basics
   149→
   150→**Here's what actually works:**
   151→1. Sleep 7-9 hours
   152→2. Eat enough protein
   153→3. Lift weights
   154→4. Use sunscreen
   155→5. Stay lean
   156→6. Groom yourself
   157→
   158→That's 90% of it. Everything else is optimization on top of this foundation. If you're not doing these six things consistently, nothing else matters.`,
   159→    },
   160→    {
   161→      id: 'mistake-5-all-or-nothing',
   162→      title: 'Mistake #5: All-or-Nothing Thinking',
   163→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   164→      content: `You miss one gym session and think "welp, the whole week is ruined."
   165→You eat one bad meal and say "might as well order pizza for the rest of the week."
   166→You skip your skincare once and abandon the routine entirely.
   167→
   168→**This is self-sabotage with extra steps.**
   169→
   170→Progress isn't linear. Life happens. The goal isn't perfection—it's **consistency over time**.
   171→
   172→Missing one day means nothing. Missing one day, then letting it spiral into one week, then one month? That's the killer.
   173→
   174→**The rule:** If you miss, just get back on track the next opportunity. No guilt, no drama. Just reset and continue.`,
   175→      tips: [
   176→        'One bad day is noise. One bad month is a pattern.',
   177→        "Never miss twice in a row—that's the real rule",
   178→        'Lower the bar if needed, but show up'
   179→      ],
   180→    },
   181→    {
   182→      id: 'mistake-6-money-before-basics',
   183→      title: 'Mistake #6: Spending Money Before Basics',
   184→      humorLevel: 'high',
   185→      content: `You're researching jaw implants but you're at 22% body fat.
   186→You want Botox but you've never worn sunscreen.
   187→You're considering hair transplants but you sleep 5 hours a night.
   188→
   189→**You're skipping chapters, my guy.**
   190→
   191→Here's the priority order:
   192→1. **Free tier:** Sleep, hydration, basic hygiene, mewing, posture
   193→2. **Low cost ($20-50/mo):** Gym, skincare basics, grooming tools
   194→3. **Medium cost ($50-200/mo):** Supplements, better products, minoxidil
   195→4. **High cost ($500+):** Treatments, procedures, surgery
   196→
   197→Don't level skip. The expensive stuff doesn't work if the foundation is garbage.
   198→
   199→Surgery on a 25% body fat face is like putting a spoiler on a Honda Civic. Fix the car first.`,
   200→      warnings: [
   201→        "Surgery doesn't fix lifestyle problems",
   202→        'Get to 12% body fat before considering facial procedures'
   203→      ],
   204→    },
   205→    {
   206→      id: 'the-real-strategy',
   207→      title: 'The Actual Strategy That Works',
   208→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   209→      content: `Here's what the successful guys do:
   210→
   211→**1. Accept the timeline**
   212→You're playing a 1-2 year game minimum. Accept that now or quit.
   213→
   214→**2. Build systems, not goals**
   215→"I want a better jawline" is a goal. "I chew mastic gum for 20 minutes after every meal" is a system. Systems win.
   216→
   217→**3. Track ruthlessly**
   218→Take monthly photos. Same lighting, same angle, same expression. This is the only objective measure.
   219→
   220→**4. Iterate slowly**
   221→Add one new thing every 4-6 weeks. Not five things at once. You need to know what's actually working.
   222→
   223→**5. Focus on the 80/20**
   224→20% of actions produce 80% of results. For most guys:
   225→- Getting lean (diet + exercise)
   226→- Skincare (cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen)
   227→- Grooming (hair, brows, facial hair)
   228→
   229→**Nail these before anything else.**`,
   230→      tips: [
   231→        'Progress compounds over time',
   232→        'Small daily actions beat occasional big efforts',
   233→        'Document everything so you can see the change'
   234→      ],
   235→      media: [
   236→        {
   237→          id: 'strategy-visual',
   238→          type: 'image',
   239→          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1434596922112-19c563067271?w=800&q=80',
   240→          alt: 'Progress and tracking',
   241→          caption: 'Track ruthlessly, iterate slowly',
   242→          placement: 'inline',
   243→        },
   244→      ],
   245→    },
   246→    {
   247→      id: 'closing',
   248→      title: 'Lock In',
   249→      humorLevel: 'high',
   250→      content: `The cope stops here. No more excuses. No more "I'll start Monday." No more blaming genetics.
   251→
   252→You have all the information you need. This app, this guide, these tools—they're more than enough.
   253→
   254→The only question is whether you're actually going to do the work or just read about it and go back to whatever you were doing before.
   255→
   256→**Your move.**
   257→
   258→Mog your past self. That's the whole game.`,
   259→    },
   260→  ],
   261→};

<system-reminder>

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

/**
 * Mindset & Beginner Mistakes Guide
 * Humor Level: High (30%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const mindsetGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'mindset',
  slug: 'mindset-mistakes',
  title: 'Mindset & Beginner Mistakes',
  subtitle: "The cope stops here",
  description: "Before you spend a dime, fix the mental game. Most guys sabotage themselves before they even start.",
  icon: 'Brain',
  humorLevel: 'high',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 1,
  tags: ['mindset', 'beginners', 'fundamentals'],
  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat'],
  productIds: [],
  forumCategory: 'anxiety',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'mindset-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1507003211169-0a1dd7228f2d?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Focused mindset and determination',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Real Talk',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're here because you want to look better. Good. That's the first step.

But here's what nobody tells you: **most guys fail not because they don't know what to do, but because their mindset is cooked from day one.**

They're either:
- Paralyzed by analysis (reading guides instead of taking action)
- Expecting overnight results (then quitting after 2 weeks)
- Comparing themselves to genetic outliers (and feeling defeated)
- Looking for shortcuts (spoiler: there aren't any)

This guide is about fixing that before you waste months spinning your wheels.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'mindset-intro',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1552674605-db6ffd4facb5?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Man focused on goals',
          caption: 'The mindset game starts before everything else',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'level-up-gif',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/H9l0FtwC2hA3V7Bj5H/giphy.gif',
          alt: 'Level Up pixel animation',
          caption: 'Time to level up',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-1-perfectionism',
      title: 'Mistake #1: Waiting for the "Perfect" Plan',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You've bookmarked 47 articles. You've saved 200 Instagram posts. You've downloaded 12 PDFs. You've done exactly **zero** actual work.

**This ain't it, chief.**

The perfect routine doesn't exist. There's no secret combination of products and exercises that will unlock chad-tier genetics. There's just consistent effort over time.

Here's the brutal truth: a mediocre plan executed consistently beats a perfect plan you never start.

**Action Step:** Pick ONE thing from this app to improve. Just one. Do it for 30 days before adding anything else.`,
      tips: [
        'Done is better than perfect',
        'Consistency beats intensity every single time',
        'Start before you feel ready'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'perfectionism-trap',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1484480974693-6ca0a78fb36b?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Planning and action',
          caption: 'Stop planning, start doing',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-2-timeline',
      title: 'Mistake #2: Expecting Fast Results',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `You started mewing yesterday and you're checking your jawline in the mirror this morning. Bro.

Real change takes **months to years**, depending on what you're working on:

| Change | Timeline |
|--------|----------|
| Better skin (routine) | 6-12 weeks |
| Body recomposition | 3-6 months |
| Posture improvement | 3-6 months |
| Hair regrowth (minox) | 6-12 months |
| Mewing (adults) | 1-2+ years |

**The guys who win are the ones who forget about results and just lock in on the process.**

Think about it: if you had started 6 months ago, you'd already be there. You didn't. So start now and stop checking daily.`,
      warnings: [
        'Taking progress photos daily will drive you insane',
        'Monthly or bi-monthly comparison photos are enough'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-3-comparison',
      title: 'Mistake #3: Comparing to Genetic Outliers',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're comparing yourself to guys who:
- Won the genetic lottery
- Have professional lighting in every photo
- Are on gear and won't admit it
- Use filters/editing
- Got surgery and claim "just mewing bro"

**This is NPC behavior.**

Here's a better frame: you're not trying to become someone else. You're trying to mog your past self. That's it.

Your only competition is the guy you were 6 months ago. If he'd be jealous of where you are now, you're winning.`,
      tips: [
        'Mog your past self, not strangers on the internet',
        'Unfollow accounts that make you feel like garbage',
        'Follow for information, not comparison'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-4-shortcuts',
      title: 'Mistake #4: Looking for Shortcuts',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `There are no shortcuts. There are no hacks. There is no "one weird trick."

The internet is full of people trying to sell you things you don't need:
- Miracle supplements that do nothing
- Expensive gadgets that collect dust
- "Secret" techniques that are just repackaged basics

**Here's what actually works:**
1. Sleep 7-9 hours
2. Eat enough protein
3. Lift weights
4. Use sunscreen
5. Stay lean
6. Groom yourself

That's 90% of it. Everything else is optimization on top of this foundation. If you're not doing these six things consistently, nothing else matters.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-5-all-or-nothing',
      title: 'Mistake #5: All-or-Nothing Thinking',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `You miss one gym session and think "welp, the whole week is ruined."
You eat one bad meal and say "might as well order pizza for the rest of the week."
You skip your skincare once and abandon the routine entirely.

**This is self-sabotage with extra steps.**

Progress isn't linear. Life happens. The goal isn't perfection—it's **consistency over time**.

Missing one day means nothing. Missing one day, then letting it spiral into one week, then one month? That's the killer.

**The rule:** If you miss, just get back on track the next opportunity. No guilt, no drama. Just reset and continue.`,
      tips: [
        'One bad day is noise. One bad month is a pattern.',
        "Never miss twice in a row—that's the real rule",
        'Lower the bar if needed, but show up'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-6-money-before-basics',
      title: 'Mistake #6: Spending Money Before Basics',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're researching jaw implants but you're at 22% body fat.
You want Botox but you've never worn sunscreen.
You're considering hair transplants but you sleep 5 hours a night.

**You're skipping chapters, my guy.**

Here's the priority order:
1. **Free tier:** Sleep, hydration, basic hygiene, mewing, posture
2. **Low cost ($20-50/mo):** Gym, skincare basics, grooming tools
3. **Medium cost ($50-200/mo):** Supplements, better products, minoxidil
4. **High cost ($500+):** Treatments, procedures, surgery

Don't level skip. The expensive stuff doesn't work if the foundation is garbage.

Surgery on a 25% body fat face is like putting a spoiler on a Honda Civic. Fix the car first.`,
      warnings: [
        "Surgery doesn't fix lifestyle problems",
        'Get to 12% body fat before considering facial procedures'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'the-real-strategy',
      title: 'The Actual Strategy That Works',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's what the successful guys do:

**1. Accept the timeline**
You're playing a 1-2 year game minimum. Accept that now or quit.

**2. Build systems, not goals**
"I want a better jawline" is a goal. "I chew mastic gum for 20 minutes after every meal" is a system. Systems win.

**3. Track ruthlessly**
Take monthly photos. Same lighting, same angle, same expression. This is the only objective measure.

**4. Iterate slowly**
Add one new thing every 4-6 weeks. Not five things at once. You need to know what's actually working.

**5. Focus on the 80/20**
20% of actions produce 80% of results. For most guys:
- Getting lean (diet + exercise)
- Skincare (cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen)
- Grooming (hair, brows, facial hair)

**Nail these before anything else.**`,
      tips: [
        'Progress compounds over time',
        'Small daily actions beat occasional big efforts',
        'Document everything so you can see the change'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'strategy-visual',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1434596922112-19c563067271?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Progress and tracking',
          caption: 'Track ruthlessly, iterate slowly',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'closing',
      title: 'Lock In',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `The cope stops here. No more excuses. No more "I'll start Monday." No more blaming genetics.

You have all the information you need. This app, this guide, these tools—they're more than enough.

The only question is whether you're actually going to do the work or just read about it and go back to whatever you were doing before.

**Your move.**

Mog your past self. That's the whole game.`,
    },
  ],
};
